awd_titl_txt: HDR TRIPODS: Data Science Principles of the Human-Machine Convergence
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop a new transdisciplinary Institute on Data Science for Intelligent Systems and People Interaction referred to as DATA-INSPIRE. This institute is premised on the belief that advances in data science principles are needed to impact the emerging paradigm of intelligent machines and their convergence with human society, and in particular to further improve the performance and better explain the operation of such machines that can accomplish diverse, real-world tasks and interact effectively with people. Fundamental notions of data science that can enhance development of intelligent machines can impact pressing problems facing our planet: healthcare, transportation, urban systems, etc. DATA-INSPIRE will bring together mathematicians, statisticians, and computer scientists for transdisciplinary research projects, new educational initiatives, workshops, and other efforts designed to catalyze a new foundational data science community focused on the development of intelligent, interactive machines. It will prepare students for transdisciplinary foundational work in data science, aid curriculum development, and involve government and industrial partners in collaborations and to aid in understanding of workforce issues resulting from use of intelligent machines.

Intelligent machines, such as robots, are evolving from simple automata performing repetitive tasks in highly structured and enclosed workspaces to sophisticated, closed-loop systems capable of satisfying human specifications in dynamic environments that include people. To manage and master the operations of complex machines and their interactions with people, it is necessary to better understand and adapt the data that drive the algorithms that control them. DATA-INSPIRE will address the following challenges. (1) Failures in tasks such as autonomous driving or robotic surgery can have devastating consequences. Data-driven solutions are often opaque computational tools for which it is impossible to verify correctness or explain failures. Formal tools, integrated with data, are needed to remove ambiguity about what causes intelligent machines to perform in certain ways. (2) Data-driven solutions frequently depend critically on vast corpora of accurately labeled training instances, which can be difficult to collect for physical operations. Tools are needed to reduce machine learning methods' dependence on large amounts of task-specific supervision. (3) Most intelligent machines need to react to sensing data under critical deadlines, which, if not met, can jeopardize operations. Mathematical and statistical analyses of the dynamics of learning and control are needed to assist with more effective real-time decision making.

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a vibrant transdisciplinary Institute on Data Science for INtelligent Systems and People Interaction (DATA-INSPIRE), one that created lasting new transdisciplinary partnerships and influenced careers of a great many participants. DATA-INSPIRE was premised on the belief that advances in data science are needed to impact the emerging paradigm of intelligent machines and their convergence with human workers, and to improve performance on real-world tasks. This requires better understanding and adapting of the data that drive algorithms controlling the machines, a key goal of the project.

Researchers were organized into teams from Computer Science, Statistics, and Mathematics: (A) Integration of Models and Data for Inference about Humans and Machines; (B) Dealing with Dynamics through a Data-informed Dynamical Systems Theory; (C) The Role of Data and Combinatorics in Scaling Intelligent, Interactive Systems. The teams developed into remarkably collaborative groups. For example, collaborators in Group B had not collaborated before. The initial robotics problems (the CS element) were such that combinatorial/topological dynamics techniques (the Math element) could be directly applied; the project’s interdisciplinary nature allowed us to recognize that inclusion of probabilistic methods (the Stat element) might significantly reduce computational cost.

Research Group A focused on enabling reasoning about reliability, safety, correctness, and scalability of machine applications. For example, it developed statistical methods to achieve more informative estimations in inverse scattering problems arising from areas such as medical imaging and seismic exploration. The group proposed a new statistical approach for resampling, widely applicable to the analysis of massive data collected from complex simulations. The Group’s proposed data-driven models of human communication promise to significantly improve human-computer interaction.  

Research Group B sought conditions under which data-driven methods in robotic control will succeed. Its work demonstrated the efficacy of using methods from combinatorial dynamics to address robotic control problems. It developed new techniques for identifying controllability for robotic systems with significantly less sampling than traditional methods. The results also have potential applicability to trophic networks and regulatory networks in systems biology.

Group C concentrated on efficient solutions for task planning involving robotic manipulators to rearrange multiple objects, a task arising in product assembly, logistics, or home automation for self-assisted living. The team improved the computational efficiency of solutions usable on tabletop setups and beyond. The results add to the capability of machine intelligence in solving task planning and scheduling problems. 

The project involved some 20 faculty, 2 postdocs, 30 graduate students from multiple departments, and 17 REU students from institutions nationwide. One postdoc came in a topologist, an abstract mathematician, and was transformed into a roboticist with deep interest in applications and transdisciplinarity. The second came focused on very classical applied mathematics and moved into studying probabilistic approaches based upon data - a big shift. Graduate students told us that DATA-INSPIRE involvement was pivotal to their academic development and cited the focus on integrating disciplines. REU students emphasized the opportunity to see what research is like through an independent project, and to make contacts they expect will last them well into their research careers.

In the seminar series, in addition to theoretical talks, applied talks covered topics such as intelligent machines and ecology, inference analyses to dissect tumor mutational profiles, and smart and accessible transportation hubs for assistive navigation. Nine workshops were on “Monte Carlo, Dynamic Systems and Robotics,” “Dynamics, Topology, and Robotic Control,” “Democratizing AI,” “Bridging Game Theory and Machine Learning for Multi-party Decision Making,” and “Algorithm and Mechanism Design for Achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals,” and other topics. Seven “Boot Camps” for advanced undergraduates and graduate students exposed them to Institute themes. For instance, one emphasized interactive analyses and visualizations of data as tools for thinking about science, introducing students to python notebooks for data science and methods for exploring, understanding, and explaining data sets. Ten transdisciplinary graduate courses covered such topics as systems biology, topological data analysis, socially cognizant robotics, and extreme values and risk.

The Institute had impacts on programs at Rutgers University and beyond. Rutgers launched a data science major, minor, and certificate program at the undergraduate level, influenced by DATA-INSPIRE. Institute faculty helped manage an initiative Advancing Women in CS. Development of new course materials aimed at appealing to women was a key part of this and utilized many ideas from Institute research. Institute faculty helped establish the Rutgers Initiative on AI & Pandemics; its work on Contact Tracing and Social Distancing was clearly influenced by DATA-INSPIRE. DATA-INSPIRE also influenced development of the Rutgers Critical AI initiative, motivated by the goal of making AI “ethical,” “democratic,” and “human-centered,” and emphasizing involvement of the humanities. A Machine Learning Challenge for Combinatorial Problems in Robotics led by DATA-INSPIRE graduate students introduced participating students from around the country to problems on object rearrangements.
